standard_metadata.standard_description: Use variables to represent quantities in a real-world or mathematical problem, and construct simple equations and inequalities to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.

question.content: You downloaded a video game to your computer.  You have a $60$-minute free trial of the game. It takes $5\dfrac{1}{6}$ minutes to set up the game and $7\dfrac{1}{3}$ minutes to play each level.  You want to find out how many levels you can play for free.  **Which inequality describes the number of levels, $\ell$, you can play in  $60$ minutes?**      **Can you play $6$ levels during your free trial?**

hints.content: You have a $60$-minute free trial of the game.  Can your total time be. . . | Response -|- Less than $60$ minutes? | **Yes** Exactly $60$ minutes? | **Yes** More than $60$ minutes? | No Conclusion| Total time $\maroonD{\leq} 60$ minutes  You will spend $\blueD{5 \dfrac{1}{6}}$ minutes setting up the game, then $7 \dfrac{1}{3}$ minutes for each level you play, so you will spend $\greenD {\left(7 \dfrac{1}{3}\right)\ell}$ minutes playing $\ell$ levels.  Together, you will spend $\blueD{5 \dfrac{1}{6}}+\greenD{\left(7 \dfrac{1}{3}\right)\ell}$ minutes.  This must be *less than or equal to* $\purpleC{60}$, so the inequality is:  $\blueD{5 \dfrac{1}{6}}+\greenD{\left(7 \dfrac{1}{3}\right)\ell}\maroonD{\leq}\purpleC{60}$

Let's substitute in $\goldE{\ell}=\goldE{6}$ to test whether the inequality is true if you play $6$ levels.  $\begin{align} 5 \dfrac{1}{6}+\left(7 \dfrac{1}{3}\right)\goldE{\ell}&\leq 60 \\\\ 5 \dfrac{1}{6}+\left(7 \dfrac{1}{3}\right)\goldE{6}&\stackrel{?}{\leq} 60 \\\\ 5 \dfrac{1}{6}+44&\stackrel{?}{\leq} 60 \\\\ 49 \dfrac{1}{6}  &\stackrel{\checkmark}{\leq} 60 \end{align}$  Substituting in $\goldE{\ell}=\goldE{6}$ makes the inequality true, so you can play $6$ levels during your free trial.
The inequality is:  $5\dfrac{1}{6}+\left(7\dfrac{1}{3}\right)\ell\le 60$  Yes, you can play $6$ levels during your free trial.

item.problemType: Type 1 - Real world problems: write inequality and find minimun/maximum value

question.content: Tatiana wants to give friendship bracelets to her $32$ classmates.  She already has $5$ bracelets, and she can buy more bracelets in packages of $4$.   **Write an inequality to determine the number of packages, $p$, Tatiana could buy to have enough bracelets.**      **Will Tatiana have enough bracelets if she buys $5$ packages?**

hints.content: Tatiana wants to give friendship bracelets to her $32$ classmates.  Can Tatiana give each classmate a bracelet if she has. . . | Response -|- Less than $32$ bracelets? | No Exactly $32$ bracelets? | **Yes** More than $32$ bracelets? | **Yes** Conclusion| Total bracelets $\maroonD{\geq} 32$  Tatiana already has $\blueD{5}$ bracelets, and gets $p$ packages with $\greenD{4}$ bracelets per package, so there will be $\greenD {4}p$ bracelets in the packages.  Therefore, she has a total of $\blueD5+\greenD{4}p$ bracelets.  This must be *greater than or equal to* $\purpleC{32}$, so the inequality is:  $\blueD{5}+\greenD{4}p\maroonD{\geq}\purpleC{32}$

Let's substitute in $\goldE{p}=\goldE{5}$ to test whether the inequality is true if Tatiana buys $5$ packages.  $\begin{align} 5+4\goldE{p} &\geq 32 \\\\ 5+4\goldE{(5)} &\stackrel{?}\geq32 \\\\ 5+20 &\stackrel{?}\geq32 \\\\ 25 &\ngeq32 \end{align}$  Substituting in $\goldE{p}=\goldE{5}$ makes the inequality false, so Tatiana will not have enough bracelets if she buys $5$ packages.
The inequality is:  $5+4p\geq 32$  No, Tatiana will not have enough bracelets if she buys $5$ packages.

item.problemType: Type 1 - Real world problems: write inequality and find minimun/maximum value

question.content: Renna pushes the elevator button, but the elevator does not move.  The mass limit for the elevator is $450$ kilograms ($\text{kg}$), but Renna and her load of identical packages mass a total of $620\,\text{kg}$.  Each package has a mass of $37.4\,\text{kg}$.  **Write an inequality to determine the number of packages, $p$,  Renna could remove from the elevator to meet the mass requirement.**      **What is the minimum whole number of packages Renna needs to remove from the elevator to meet the mass requirement?**     packages

hints.content: The mass limit for the elevator is $450\,\text{kg}$.  Will Renna meet the mass limit if the total mass is. . . | Response -|- Less than $450\,\text{kg}$? | **Yes** Exactly $450\,\text{kg}$? | **Yes** More than $450\,\text{kg}$? | No Conclusion| Total mass $\maroonD{\leq} 450\,\text{kg}$  Renna and her load of identical packages weigh a total of $\blueD{620}\,\text{kg}$. Each of the packages masses $\greenD{37.4}\,\text{kg}$, so the mass of $p$ packages is $\greenD{37.4}p\,\text{kg}$.  Therefore, after Renna removes $p$ packages from the elevator, the total mass of Renna and the remaining packages will be:  $\blueD{620}-\greenD{37.4}p$  This must be *less than or equal to* $\purpleC{450}$, so the inequality is:  $\blueD{620}-\greenD{37.4}p\maroonD{\leq}\purpleC{450}$

Let's start by subtracting $\blueD{620}$ from both sides of the inequality.  Remember that  when we divide an inequality by a negative number, the inequality sign *reverses*.  $\begin{align} 620 - 37.4p &\leq 450 \\\\ 620 -\blueD{620} - 37.4p &\leq 450 -\blueD{620}\\\\ -37.4p &\leq -170 \\\\ \dfrac{-37.4p}{\green{-37.4}} &\redD{\geq} \dfrac{-170}{\green{-37.4}} \\\\ p &\redD{\geq} \dfrac{-170}{-37.4} \\\\ p &\redD{\geq} 4\dfrac{6}{11} \end{align}$

Because Renna cannot remove $\dfrac{6}{11}$ of a package from the elevator, this means that she needs to remove $5$ or more packages to meet the mass requirement.  So Renna needs to remove a minimum of $5$ packages.
The inequality is:  $620-37.4p\le 450$  Renna needs to remove a minimum of $5$ packages from the elevator to meet the mass requirement.

item.problemType: Type 1 - Real world problems: write inequality and find minimun/maximum value

question.content: Kim's softball team was playing in the championship game.  When there were $4$ innings left, the team was losing by a score of $17$ to $6$ runs.  In the last $4$ innings, her team scored the same number of runs per inning, and the other team did not score  any more runs. Kim's team won with the most runs.  **Write an  inequality to determine the number of runs per inning, $p$, Kim's team could have scored.**    **Find the minimum whole number of runs per inning Kim's team could have scored.**   runs per inning

hints.content: Kim's team needed more than $17$ runs to win.  Would Kim's team win with . . | Response -|- Less than $17$ runs? | No Exactly $17$ runs? | No More than $17$ runs? | **Yes** Conclusion| Total runs $\maroonD{>} 17$  Kim's team already had $\blueD{6}$ runs.    Since they scored $p$ runs per inning for $\greenD{4}$ innings, they scored an additional $\green{4}p$ runs, so Kim's team had a total of $\blueD6+\greenD{4}p$ runs.  This must be *greater than* $\purpleC{17}$, so the inequality is:  $\blue6+\greenD{4}p\maroonD>\purpleC{17}$

We can start by subtracting $\blueD{6}$ from both sides of the inequality:  $\begin{align} 6 + 4p &> 17 \\\\ 6- \blueD{6}+ 4p &> 17- \blueD{6}\\\\ 4p &> 11 \\\\ \dfrac{4p}{\greenD{4}} &> \dfrac{11}{\greenD{4}}\\ \\ p &> 2\dfrac34 \end{align}$  Kim's team must score *more* than $2\dfrac34$ runs per inning to win the game. So Kim's team must have scored a minimum of $3$ runs per inning.
The inequality is:  $6+4p>17$  Kim's team scored a minimum of $3$ runs per inning.

item.problemType: Type 1 - Real world problems: write inequality and find minimun/maximum value

question.content: You have $\$20$ to spend on taxi fare.  The ride costs $\$5$ plus $\$2.50$ per kilometer.    **Write an inequality to determine the distance in kilometers, $d$, you can ride for $\$20$.**       **What is the maximum distance, in kilometers, you can ride for $\$20?$**     kilometers

hints.content: You have $\$20$ to spend on taxi fare.  Can you afford to spend . . | Response -|- Less than $\$20$? | **Yes** Exactly $\$20$? | **Yes** More than $\$20$? | No Conclusion| Total dollars $\maroonD{\leq} 20$  The total cost of the taxi is $\blueD{\$5}$ plus the amount it costs to go $d$ kilometers at $\greenD{\$2.50}$ per kilometer, which is $\greenD{2.5}d$.  The total cost of riding the taxi $d$ kilometers is $\blueD5+\greenD{2.5}d$ dollars.  This amount must be *less than or equal to* $\purpleC{20}$, so the inequality is:  $\blueD5+\greenD{2.5}d\maroonD{\leq}\purpleC{20}$

To solve, let's start by subtracting $\blueD{5}$ from both sides of the inequality:  $\begin{align} 5+2.5d&\leq20\\\\ 5+2.5d -\blueD{5} &\leq20- \blueD{5} \\\\ 2.5d &\leq 15\\ \\ \dfrac{2.5d}{\greenD{2.5}} &\leq \dfrac{15}{\greenD{2.5}}\\\\ d &\leq6 \end{align}$  You can ride a maximum of $6$ kilometers.
The inequality is:  $5 + 2.5d  \leq 20$   You can ride a maximum of $6$ kilometers for $\$20$.

item.problemType: Type 1 - Real world problems: write inequality and find minimun/maximum value

question.content: Mrs. Morton has a special reward system for her class.  When all her students behave well, she rewards them by putting $3$ marbles into a marble jar.  When the jar has  $100$ or more marbles, the students have a party. Right now, the jar has $24$ marbles.    **Write an inequality to determine the number of additional times, $r$, Mrs. Morton could reward the class in order for the students to have a party.**      **Will the students have a party if Mrs. Morton rewards them $31$ additional times?**

hints.content: When the jar has  $100$ or more marbles, the students have a party.  Will the students have a party if the jar has. . . | Response -|- Less than $100$ marbles? | No Exactly $100$ marbles? | **Yes** More than $100$ marbles? | **Yes** Conclusion| Total marbles $\maroonD{\geq} 100$  The jar in Mrs. Morton's class has $\blueD{24}$ marbles, plus the number of marbles for $r$ rewards at $3$ marbles per reward, so the number of marbles added for $r$ rewards is $\green{3}r$.  After the students earn $r$ rewards, the jar has a total of $\blueD{24}+\greenD{3}r$ marbles.  The number of marbles must be *greater than or equal to* $\purpleC{100}$, so the inequality is:  $\blueD{24}+\greenD{3}r\maroonD{\geq}\purpleC{100}$

Let's substitute in $\goldE{r}=\goldE{31}$ to test whether the inequality is true if Mrs. Morton rewards the students $31$ additional times.  $\begin{align} 24+3\goldE{r}&\geq100 \\\\ 24+3\cdot\goldE{31}&\stackrel{?}\geq100 \\\\ 24+93&\stackrel{?}\geq100 \\\\ 117&\stackrel{\checkmark}\geq100 \\\\ \end{align}$  Substituting in $\goldE{r}=\goldE{31}$ makes the inequality true, so Mrs. Morton could reward the class $31$ additional times.
The inequality is:  $24 + 3r \geq 100$  Yes, the students will have a party if Mrs. Morton rewards them $31$ additional times.

item.problemType: Type 1 - Real world problems: write inequality and find minimun/maximum value

question.content: Joey Chestnut is trying to break his own record for eating the most whole hot dogs in $10$ minutes.  He needs to eat more than $72$ hot dogs to break his record. After $1$ minute, Joey has eaten $11 \dfrac{1}{4}$ hot dogs.  Let $d$ represent the number of hot dogs Joey eats per minute for the next $9$ minutes.  **Which inequality represents the number of hot dogs per minute Joey could eat for the last $9$ minutes to break his record?**       **Will Joey break his record if he eats $6$ hot dogs per minute for the next $9$ minutes?**

hints.content: Joey needs to eat more than $72$ hot dogs to break his record.  Will Joey break his record if he eats . . | Response -|- Less than $72$ hot dogs? | No Exactly $72$ hot dogs? | No More than $72$ hot dogs? | **Yes** Conclusion| Total hot dogs $\maroonD{>} 72$  Joey  has already eaten $\blueD{11\dfrac{1}{4}}$ hot dogs. If he eats $d$ hot dogs per minute for $\greenD{9}$ minutes, he will have eaten  $\greenD{9}d$ additional hot dogs.  The total number of hot dogs is then:  $\blueD{11\dfrac{1}{4}}+\greenD{9}d$  This must be *greater than* $\purpleC{72}$, so the inequality is:  $\blueD{11\dfrac{1}{4}}+\greenD{9}d\maroonD{>}\purpleC{72}$

Let's substitute in $\goldE{d}=\goldE{6}$ to test whether the inequality is true if Joey eats $6$ hot dogs per minute.  $\begin{align} 11\dfrac{1}{4}+9\goldD{d}&>72\\\\ 11\dfrac{1}{4}+9 \cdot \goldD{6}&\stackrel{?}{>}72\\\\ 11\dfrac{1}{4}+54&\stackrel{?}{>}72\\\\ 65\dfrac{1}{4}&\ngtr72 \end{align}$  Substituting in $\goldE{d}=\goldE{6}$ makes the inequality false, so Joey will not break his record if he eats $6$ hot dogs per minute.
The inequality is:   $11\dfrac{1}{4}+9d>72$  No, Joey will not break his record if he eats $6$ hot dogs per minute for the next $9$ minutes.

item.problemType: Type 1 - Real world problems: write inequality and find minimun/maximum value

question.content: Janie has $\$3$.  She earns $\$1.20$ for each chore she does and can do fractions of chores.  She wants to earn enough money to buy a CD for $\$13.50$.  **Write an inequality to determine the number of chores, $c$, Janie could do to have enough money to buy the CD.**    **Graph the solution set to this inequality.**

hints.content: Janey wants to earn enough money to buy a CD for $\$13.50$.  Can Janey buy the CD if she has. . . | Response -|- Less than $\$13.50$? | No Exactly $\$13.50$? | **Yes** More than $\$13.50$? | **Yes** Conclusion| Total dollars $\maroonD{\geq} 13.50$  If Janie does $c$ chores, she will earn $\greenD{1.2}c$ dollars for doing chores, plus $\blueD{3}$ dollars she already has.  The amount she has is :  $\blueD{3}+\greenD{1.2}c$  This amount must be *greater than or equal to* $\purpleC{13.50}$, so the inequality is:  $\blueD{3}+\greenD{1.2c}\maroonD{\geq}\purpleC{13.50}$

To solve the inequality, let's start by subtracting $\blueD{3}$ from both sides of the inequality:  $\begin{align} 3+1.2c &≥ 13.5\\\\ 3+1.2c -\blueD{3} &≥ 13.5- \blueD{ 3}\\\\ 1.2c &≥ 10.5 \\\\ \dfrac{1.2c}{\greenD{1.2}} &≥ \dfrac{10.5}{\greenD{1.2}}\\ \\ c &≥ 8.75 \end{align}$  Janie must do $8.75$ or more chores to have enough money to purchase the CD.

To graph the inequality $c\geq 8.75$, we first draw a circle at $8.75$.  This circle divides the number line into two sections: one that contains solutions to the inequality and one that does not.    The solution  includes the point $c=8.75$, so we *fill in* the circle at $8.75$.  Because the solution to the inequality says that $c\geq 8.75$, this means that solutions are numbers to the *right* of $8.75$.
The inequality is:  $3+1.2c\geq 13.50$  The graph of the solution of the inequality, $c ≥ 8.75$, looks like this:  [[☃ number-line 3]]

item.problemType: Type 2 - Real world problems: write inequality and graph solution

question.content: Katie wants to collect over $100$ seashells. She already has $34$ seashells in her collection. Each day, she finds $12$ more seashells on the beach.  Katie can use fractions of days to find seashells.  **Write an inequality to determine the number of days, $d$, it will take  Katie to collect over $100$ seashells.**    **Graph the solution set to this inequality.**

hints.content: Katie wants to collect over $100$ seashells.  Does Katie want to collect. . . | Response -|- Less than $100$ seashells? |No Exactly $100$ seashells? | No More than $100$ seashells? | **Yes** Conclusion| Total shells $\maroonD{>} 100$  Katie already has $\blueD{34}$ seashells. If she collects $\greenD{12}$ seashells per day for $d$ more days, she will have $\greenD{12}d$ additional seashells.  After $d$ days, Katie will have a total of $\blueD{34}+\greenD{12}d$ seashells in her collection.  This amount must be *greater than* $\purpleC{100}$, so the inequality is:  $\blueD{34}+\greenD{12}d\maroonD{>}\purpleC{100}$

To solve the inequality, let’s start by subtracting $\blueD{34}$ from both sides:  $\begin{align} 34 + 12d &> 100\\\\ 34- \blueD{34} + 12d &> 100- \blueD{34}\\\\ 12d &> 66\\\\ \dfrac{12d}{\greenD{12}} &> \dfrac{66}{\greenD{12}}\\ \\ d &> 5\dfrac{1}{2} \end{align}$  Katie must collect seashells for more than $5\dfrac{1}{2}$ days.

To graph the inequality $d>5\dfrac{1}{2}$, we first **draw a circle at  $5\dfrac{1}{2}$**.  This circle divides the number line into two sections: one that contains solutions to the inequality and one that does not.    The solution does not include the point $d=5\dfrac{1}{2}$, so the circle at $5\dfrac{1}{2}$ is **not filled in**.  Because the solution to the inequality says that $d>5\dfrac{1}{2}$, this means that solutions are numbers to the **right** of $5\dfrac{1}{2}$.
The inequality is:  $34+12d>100$  The graph that represents the solution of the inequality,  $d > 5\dfrac{1}{2}$,  looks like this:  [[☃ number-line 1]]

item.problemType: Type 2 - Real world problems: write inequality and graph solution

question.content: The latest online craze is a new game, Khan on Seven.  You get $100$ points for playing the game. In addition, you get $50$ points for each seven-letter word you make with the ten letters you receive. Sal wants to break the record, and he needs  $18{,}000$ or more points to do so.  **Write an inequality to determine the number of seven-letter words, $w$, Sal could make to break the record.**    **Graph the solution set to this inequality.**

hints.content: Sal wants to break the record, and he needs  $18{,}000$ points or more to do so.  Will Sal break the record if he earns . . . | Response -|- Less than $18{,}000$ points? | No Exactly $18{,}000$ points? | **Yes** More than $18{,}000$ points? | **Yes** Conclusion| Total points $\maroonD{\geq} 18{,}000$  Sal  gets $\blueD{100}$ points for playing the game, plus $\greenD{50}$ points per word for  $w$ seven-letter words, or $\greenD{50}w$ points. If he makes $w$ seven-letter words, Sal will have a total of $\blueD{100}+\greenD{50}w$ points.    This must be *greater than or equal to* $\purpleC{18{,}000}$, so the inequality is:  $\blueD{100}+\greenD{50}w\maroonD{\geq}\purpleC{18{,}000}$

To solve the inequality, let’s start by subtracting $\blueD{100}$ from both sides:  $\begin{align} 100+50w &\geq 18{,}000\\\\ 100+50w- \blueD{100} &\geq18{,}000- \blueD{100}\\\\   50w&\geq 17{,}900\\\\ \dfrac{50w}{\greenD{50}} &\geq \dfrac{17{,}900}{\greenD{50}}\\\\ w &\geq 358 \end{align}$  Sal must make at least $358$ seven-letter words to break the record!

To graph the inequality $w\geq358$, we first **draw a circle at  $358$**.  This circle divides the number line into two sections: one that contains solutions to the inequality and one that does not.    The solution  includes the point $w=358$, so the **circle at $358$ is filled in**.  Because the solution to the inequality says that $w\geq358$, this means that solutions are numbers to the **right** of $358$.
The inequality is:  $100+50w\geq18{,}000$  The graph that represents the solution of the inequality,  $w\geq358$,  looks like this:   [[☃ number-line 1]]

item.problemType: Type 2 - Real world problems: write inequality and graph solution

question.content: Darcie wants to crochet a minimum of $3$ blankets to donate to a homeless shelter. Darcie crochets at a rate of $\dfrac{1}{15}$ of a blanket per day. She has $60$ days until when she wants to donate the blankets, but she also wants to skip crocheting some days so she can volunteer in other ways.  **Write an inequality to determine the number of days, $s$, Darcie can skip crocheting and still meet her goal.**    **Graph the solution set to this inequality.**

hints.content: Darcie wants to donate a minimum of $3$ blankets.  Will Darcie meet her goal if she crochets . . | Response -|- Less than $3$ blankets? | No Exactly $3$ blankets? | **Yes** More than $3$ blankets? | **Yes** Conclusion| Total blankets $\maroonD{\geq} 3$  If Darcie skips $s$ days, then she will crochet for $\goldE{60-s}$ days. Darcie crochets at a rate of $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{15}}$ of a blanket per day, so she can crochet a total of $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{15}}(\goldE{60-s})$ blankets.    This amount must be *greater than or equal to* $\purpleC{3}$ blankets, so the inequality is:  $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{15}}(\goldE{60-s})\maroonD{\geq}\purpleC{3}$

To solve the inequality, let's start by multiplying both sides by $\blueD{15}$.   Remember that  when we multiply an inequality by a negative number, the inequality sign *reverses*.  $\begin{align} \dfrac{1}{15}(60-s)&\geq 3 \\\\ \blueD{15}\cdot \dfrac{1}{15}(60-s)&\geq \blueD{15} \cdot 3 \\\\ 60-s &\geq 45 \\\\ 60-s \gray{-60} &\geq 45\gray{-60} \\\\ -s &\geq -15 \\\\ -s\tealD{\cdot -1} &\redD{\leq} -15\tealD{\cdot -1}  \\\\ s &\redD{\leq} 15 \end{align}$  Darcie can skip no more than $15$ days of crocheting to meet her goal.

To graph the inequality $s \leq 15$, we first **draw a circle at $15$**.  This circle divides the number line into two sections: one that contains solutions to the inequality and one that does not.    The solution includes the point $s=15$, so the circle at  $15$ is **filled in**.  Because the solution to the inequality says that $s\leq 15$, this means that solutions are numbers to the **left** of $15$.
The inequality is:  $\dfrac{1}{15}(60-s)\geq 3$  The graph of the solution of the inequality, $s \leq 15$, looks like this:   [[☃ number-line 2]]

item.problemType: Type 2 - Real world problems: write inequality and graph solution

question.content: Noor brought $21$ sheets of stickers. She gave $\dfrac{1}{3}$ of a sheet to each of the $45$ students at recess. She wants to give teachers $1\dfrac{1}{2}$ sheets each.   **Which inequality describes the number of teachers, $t$, Noor could give sheets of stickers to?**      **What is the solution set of the inequality?**    $t$

hints.content: Noor brought $21$ sheets of stickers.  Can Noor give away. . . | Response -|- Less than $21$ sheets? | **Yes** Exactly $21$ sheets? | **Yes** More than $21$ sheets? | No Conclusion| Total sheets $\maroonD{\leq} 21$  Noor gave $\dfrac{1}{3}$ of a sheet to each of the $45$ students, so she gave $\blueD{15}$ sheets to students because $\dfrac{1}{3}\cdot 45=15$. She wants to give each teacher $\greenD{1\dfrac{1}{2}}$ sheets of stickers. She wants to give a total of  $\greenD{\dfrac{3}{2}}t$ sheets to the $t$ teachers because $\greenD{1\dfrac{1}{2}}\cdot t=\greenD{\dfrac{3}{2}}t$.   Noor will give away a total of $\blueD{15}+\greenD{\dfrac{3}{2}}t$ sheets of stickers.  This must be *less than or equal to* $\purpleC{21}$ sheets, so the inequality is:  $\blueD{15}+\greenD{\dfrac{3}{2}}t \maroonD{\leq} \purpleC{21}$

Let's start by subtracting $\blueD{15}$ from both sides of the inequality.   $\begin{align} 15+\dfrac{3}{2}t &\leq 21 \\\\ 15+\dfrac{3}{2}t - \blueD{15} &\leq 21 - \blueD{15}\\\\ \dfrac{3}{2}t &\leq 6 \\\\ \goldE{\dfrac{2}{3}}\cdot\dfrac{3}{2}t &\leq \goldE{\dfrac{2}{3}}\cdot 6\\\\ t &\leq 4 \end{align}$  Noor can give sheets of stickers to up to $4$ teachers.
The inequality is:   $15+\dfrac{3}{2}t\le 21$  The solution set is $t\leq 4$.

item.problemType: Type 3 - Math problem - write inequality and solve

question.content: The bottom of Ignacio's desktop is $74.5\,\text{cm}$ from the floor. Ignacio sits in his adjustable chair, and the tops of his legs are $49.3\,\text{cm}$ from the floor. Each clockwise rotation of the knob on the chair raises Ignacio's legs by $4.8\,\text{cm}$.  **Write an inequality to determine the number of clockwise rotations, $r$, Ignacio could make with the knob without his legs touching the desk.**      **What is the solution set of the inequality?**    $r$

hints.content: The bottom of Ignacio's desktop is $74.5\,\text{cm}$ from the floor. He does not want his legs to touch the bottom of the desk, so he wants the tops of  his legs to be *lower* than the bottom of the desk.  Will Ignacio's legs be lower than the desk at a height of. . . | Response -|- Less than $74.5\,\text{cm}$? | **Yes** Exactly $74.5\,\text{cm}$? | No More than $74.5\,\text{cm}$? | No Conclusion| Leg height $\maroonD{<} 74.5$  Ignacio's legs are already $\blueD{49.3}\,\text{cm}$ above the floor. Each rotation raises them by $\greenD{4.8}\,\text{cm}$ more, so $r$ rotations raises them by $\greenD{4.8}r\,\text{cm}$.  After $r$ rotations, Ignatio's legs will be $\blueD{49.3}+\greenD{4.8}r\,\text{cm}$ above the floor.  This must be *less than* $\purpleC{74.5}\,\text{cm}$, so the inequality is:  $\blueD{49.3}+\greenD{4.8}r \maroonD{<} \purpleC{74.5}$

Let's start by subtracting $\blueD{49.3}$ from both sides of the inequality.   $\begin{align} 49.3+4.8r &<74.5 \\\\ 49.3+4.8r \blueD{-49.3}&<74.5 \blueD{-49.3} \\\\ 4.8r&<25.2 \\\\ \dfrac{4.8r}{\greenD{4.8}} &<\dfrac{25.2}{\greenD{4.8}} \\\\ r &< \dfrac{21}{4} \\\\ r &< 5.25 \end{align}$  Ignacio can make less than $5.25$ rotations without his legs touching the desk.
The inequality is:  $49.3+4.8r <74.5$  The solution set is $r < 5.25$.

item.problemType: Type 3 - Math problem - write inequality and solve

question.content: Mustafa, Heloise, and Gia have written more than a combined total of $22$ articles for the school newspaper. Heloise has written $\dfrac{1}{4}$ as many articles as Mustafa has. Gia has written $\dfrac{3}{2}$ as many articles as Mustafa has.  **Write an inequality to determine the number of articles, $m$, Mustafa could have written for the school newspaper.**      **What is the solution set of the inequality?**

hints.content: Mustafa, Heloise, and Gia have written more than a combined total of $22$ articles for the school newspaper.  Is the total number of articles. . . | Response -|- Less than $22$ articles? | No Exactly $22$ articles? | No More than $22$ articles? | **Yes** Conclusion| Total articles $\maroonD{>} 22$  Mustafa has written $m$ articles. Heloise has written $\dfrac{1}{4}m$ articles. Gia has written $\dfrac{3}{2}m$ articles.  They have written a combined total of $\blueD{m+\dfrac{1}{4}m+\dfrac{3}{2}m}$ articles.  This must be *more than* $\purpleC{22}$ articles, so the inequality is:  $\blueD{m+\dfrac{1}{4}m+\dfrac{3}{2}m} \maroonD{>}\purpleC{22}$

Let's start by combining like terms.  $\begin{align} m+\dfrac{1}{4}m+\dfrac{3}{2}m&>22 \\\\ \dfrac{4}{4}m+\dfrac{1}{4}m+\dfrac{6}{4}m&>22 \\\\ \dfrac{11}{4}m&>22 \\\\ \goldD{\dfrac{4}{11}}\cdot\dfrac{11}{4}m&>\goldD{\dfrac{4}{11}}\cdot 22 \\\\ m &> 8 \end{align}$  Mustafa has written more than $8$ articles.
The inequality is:  $m+\dfrac{1}{4}m+\dfrac{3}{2}m>22$  The solution set is $m>8$.

item.problemType: Type 3 - Math problem - write inequality and solve

question.content: The swimming pool is open when the high temperature is higher than $20^\circ\text{C}$. Lainey tried to swim on Monday and Thursday (which was $3$ days later). The pool was open on Monday, but it was closed on Thursday. The high temperature was $30^\circ\text{C}$ on Monday, but decreased at a constant rate in the next $3$ days.  **Write an inequality to determine the rate, $d$, of temperature decrease in degrees Celsius per day from Monday to Thursday.**      **What is the solution set of the inequality?**    $d$

hints.content: The swimming pool is open when the high temperature is more than $20^\circ\text{C}$. We want to know about temperatures when the pool is *closed*.  Is the pool *closed* when the temperature is. . . | Response -|- Less than $20^\circ\text{C}$? | **Yes** Exactly $20^\circ\text{C}$? | **Yes** More than $20^\circ\text{C}$? | No Conclusion| Temperature $\maroonD{\leq} 20$  The high temperature was $\blueD{30^\circ\text{C}}$ on Monday. The temperature was $d^\circ\text{C}$ cooler each day, so $\greenD{3}$ days later, it was $\greenD{3}d^\circ\text{C}$ cooler than it was on Monday.  Three days after Monday, it was $\blueD{30}-\greenD{3}d^\circ\text{C}$.  This must be *less than or equal to* $\purpleC{20}^\circ\text{C}$, so the inequality is:  $\blueD{30}-\greenD{3d}\maroonD{\leq}\purpleC{20}$  [[☃ explanation 1]]

Let's start by subtracting $\blueD{30}$ from both sides of the inequality.   Remember that  when we divide an inequality by a negative number, the inequality sign *reverses*.  $\begin{align} 30-3d&\leq20 \\\\ 30-3d-\blueD{30}&\leq20 -\blueD{30}\\\\ -3d&\leq -10\\\\ \dfrac{-3d}{\goldD{-3}}&\redD{\geq} \dfrac{-10}{\goldD{-3}}\\\\ d&\redD{\geq} \dfrac{10}{3} \end{align}$  The high temperature decreased by at least $\dfrac{10}{3}$ degrees Celsius per day from Monday to Thursday.
The inequality is:  $30-3d\leq20$  The solution set is $d\geq \dfrac{10}{3}$.

item.problemType: Type 3 - Math problem - write inequality and solve

question.content: Shane and Abha earned a team badge that required their team to collect no less than $2000$ cans for recycling. Abha collected $178$ more cans than Shane did.  **Write an inequality to determine the number of cans, $S$, that Shane could have collected.**      **What is the solution set of the inequality?**    $S$

hints.content: The badge required the team to collect no less than $2000$ cans for recycling.  Can the team earn the badge for collecting. . . | Response -|- Less than $2000$ cans? | No Exactly $2000$ cans? | **Yes** More than $2000$ cans? | **Yes** Conclusion| Total cans $\maroonD{\geq} 2000$  Shane collected $\blueD{S}$ cans. Abha collected $178$ more cans, so she collected $\greenD{S+178}$ cans.  The team collected a total of $\blueD{S}+\greenD{S+178}$ cans.  This must be *greater than or equal to* $\purpleC{2000}$ cans, so the inequality is:  $\blueD{S}+\greenD{S+178}\maroonD{\geq}\purpleC{2000}$

Let's start by combining like terms.  $\begin{align} S+S+178 &\geq 2000 \\\\ 2S+178 &\geq 2000 \\\\ 2S+178\goldE{-178} &\geq 2000\goldE{-178} \\\\ 2S &\geq 1822 \\\\ \dfrac{2S}{\redD{2}} &\geq \dfrac{1822}{\redD{2}} \\\\ S &\geq 911 \end{align}$  Shane collected at least $911$ cans for recycling.
The inequality is:  $S+S+178 \geq 2000$  The solution set is $S \geq 911$.

item.problemType: Type 3 - Math problem - write inequality and solve

question.content: The dance committee of Pine Bluff Middle School earns $\$72$ from a bake sale and will earn $\$4$ for each ticket they sell to the Spring Fling dance. The dance will cost $\$400$.  **Write an inequality to determine the number, $t$, of tickets the committee could sell to have money left over after they pay for this year's dance.**      **What is the solution set of the inequality?**

hints.content: The Spring Fling dance will cost $\$400$.  Will there be leftover money if the committee earns . . . | Response -|- Less than $\$400$? | No Exactly $\$400$? | No More than $\$400$? | **Yes** Conclusion| Total dollars $\maroonD{>} 400$  The committee has $\blueD{72}$ dollars plus the amount they will earn by selling $t$ tickets at $\greenD{\$4}$ per ticket, which is $\greenD{4}t$ dollars.  The committee will earn a total of $\blueD{72}+\greenD{4}t$ dollars.  This amount  must be *greater than* $\purpleC{400}$, so the inequality is:  $\blueD{72}+\greenD{4}t\maroonD{>}\purpleC{400}$

To solve, let's start by subtracting $\blueD{72}$ from both sides of the inequality:  $\begin{align} 72+4t&>400 \\\\ 72+4t -\blueD{72} &> 400- \blueD{72} \\\\ 4t &> 328\\\\ \dfrac{4t}{\green{4}} &> \dfrac{328}{\green{4}}\\ \\ t &> 82 \end{align}$  The  committee must sell more than $82$ tickets to have money left over after paying for the dance.
The inequality is:  ${72} + 4t > 400$  The solution set is $t> 82$.

item.problemType: Type 3 - Math problem - write inequality and solve
